title: stompix
author: stompix
content: Seeing fees at below 2sat/vb and blocks still packed with tiny runes tx I was curious what do these people still minting nowadays, as the other obvious question, why in the name of god they still do will probably never have an answer.Here is a screenshot from a rune explorer:Yup, so besides SUGARBEAR•BTC•DOG, SUGARBEAR•THE•BTC•DOG, THE•BITCOIN•DOG•SUGARBEAR, THE•BTC•DOG•SUGARBEAR, SUGARBEAR•THE•BITCOIN•DOG, BTC•DOG•SUGARBEAR *no, I'm not joking about the names, they actually exist) we have now the alphabet people trying to see how many combinations of random letters can be inscribed in the chain!And if you're wondering about the numbers, yes we have close to 120 000 runes now in the chain!I feel like we're coming close to a paradox scenario where cheap fees allow everything to be written in the chain while preventing the mempool to ever be empty while at the same time having little to no actual usage in terms of real transfers because what's cheap for people wanting to engrave their legacy on the chain much like they do when scribbling their name on monuments will still be too expensive for day to day shopping.

comments.author: NeuroticFish
comments.body: Quote from: stompix on October 05, 2024, 03:09:52 PMI feel like we're coming close to a paradox scenario where cheap fees allow everything to be written in the chain while preventing the mempool to ever be empty while at the same time having little to no actual usage in terms of real transfers because what's cheap for people wanting to engrave their legacy on the chain much like they do when scribbling their name on monuments will still be too expensive for day to day shopping.I expect that the inscribing will go out of fashion and nobody will care to buy that crap any longer. Of course, some different mania may have to start for that.On the other hand, I find the block times, the big price fluctuation and the incentive of hoarding bigger impediments to day to day shopping than the fees.Well, sometimes the fees too, but imho they are the 3rd or 4th impediment in the list (or lower, if I've missed something).

comments.author: stompix
comments.created_time: October 05, 2024, 03:33:37 PMLast edit: October 05, 2024, 05:34:20 PM by stompix
comments.body: Quote from: NeuroticFish on October 05, 2024, 03:21:43 PMI expect that the inscribing will go out of fashion and nobody will care to buy that crap any longer. Of course, some different mania may have to start for that.I was thinking in terms of economics, that guy got sentenced 6 months and 20 000 euros for carving a K, that's one letter on the Colloseum walls and this didn't deter a ton of other morons to try the same, knowing from the start their traces might be erased and that nobody actually cared. But right now, the last block fee carries $2,648 in tx, so with roughly $5000 you could strike a deal with a mining pool and itch a full block by yourself and that will be there for eternity! It takes fewer spectators than the Superbowl to claim all blocks of the year at these prices and it's cheaper too!

comments.author: Dunamisx
comments.body: This also makes me remember the time Binance exchange made a change in policy to allow low capital fund projects be listed on their exchange, but later on, they discover that they have to delist as many as possible coins and tokens because of the same reason, which is lack of investors and capital fund for a project to exist.Now back to your own opinion on lower fees, in life, we should always consider the two sides of a thing, both the good one and the bad one, if we are having higher fees and many projects are still making it up to afford on this, that does not create the justification that we are not going to come across shitcoins or crypto network challenges like scam, hacks and attacks of different kinds, but we should not because of a single demerit, forfeit the whole advance we may have from the entire decentralized networks, we cant stop evil, but we can prevent ourself from being a victim of one.

comments.author: crwth
comments.body: I believe it will never end, knowing that people would take advantage of low fees whether it is daily transactions or inscribing runes just for laughs or something, it will still continue. This trend would just change once there is a significant change in fees for BTC. It is a great time to experiment with this lol.

comments.author: BlackHatCoiner
comments.body: To me, an empty mempool is a bad sign, and I hope we never experience one again. Yes, it allows me to make cheap on-chain transfers, but the bigger issue is that it indicates people aren't using Bitcoin, which will ultimately impact not just me, but the entire network.I don't mind what's being broadcasted, as long as it pays a sufficient fee. An empty mempool is a sign of a dead network.

comments.author: NeuroticFish
comments.body: Quote from: stompix on October 05, 2024, 03:33:37 PMI was thinking in terms of economics, that guy got sentenced 6 months and 20 000 euros for carving a K, that's one letter on the Collsoeum wallsPeople don't care yet about how big does the blockchain is getting and the added overall cost for each and everyone having the entire blockchain on their HDD/SSD.We are still early and.. well, for now what @BlackHatCoiner wrote makes more sense than some morons "writing letter K" into blockchain because it's cheap.Imho there should have been added a common sense limit to minimize/stop this, but some started crying they are being repressed.

They literally fought in the blocksize wars over it, splintered the community, set off the rise of the shitcoins, and forced many companies to move their businesses away from Bitcoin as they felt they could no longer trust core developers to prioritize blockchain usage over their own patented L2 solution.

comments.author: Upgrade00
comments.body: Quote from: BlackHatCoiner on October 05, 2024, 04:35:44 PMI don't mind what's being broadcasted, as long as it pays a sufficient fee. An empty mempool is a sign of a dead network. I don't think we've gotten to a point where we need runes to fill up the mempool and churn out regular transactions to keep it that way. I'll much rather have an actual account of how much real use Bitcoin is getting and what could be influencing that.If we need indirect transactions to keep the mempool alive, the network will already be dead.

comments.author: lionheart78
comments.body: People especially those who want to profit from anything will look for new things to entice people or attract people into looking and investing in their scheme.  So this kind of madness will ever be existing in the Bitcoin network regardless it is in laye 1 or layer 2 or helpful or disastrous for the Bitcoin blockchain.  These people never consider other things than making money for themselves.It is sad that developers have never done anything to stop this kind of madness, the ones suffering are the legit people who only want to make use of the Bitcoin network for day-to-day transactions.Quote from: o48o on October 05, 2024, 10:32:58 PMThat's how freedom looks like. It's never resembles our idealistic view about it. It's never "good", because others are doing it "wrong". comments.author: d5000
comments.body: I think it will eventually die down, abeit slowly. It's a good sign in my opinion that now with the low fees Runes activity has not increased, but instead is very slowly declining, with occasional mini-waves.On September 29, a new "all time low" of wallets (I guess, addresses?) interacting with Runes for the first time was recorded, just about 12000. On normal days it's still close to 20000.Source: CryptoKoryo - you can see there that basically all indicators have stalled, and the last major waves in August and (much smaller already) September have also ended.

When the market comes to time when fear is dominating, and greed is less existing, these hyped madness like Ordinals, Runes will die with time.Bitcoin Cash, a shit coin is an example. 7 years after a hard fork year in 2017, in 2024 and 2025, it's really hard for Bitcoin Cash team to create a new greed trend on their blockchain and that shit coin.

comments.body: Quote from: NeuroticFish on October 05, 2024, 04:48:24 PMPeople don't care yet about how big does the blockchain is getting and the added overall cost for each and everyone having the entire blockchain on their HDD/SSD.Imho there should have been added a common sense limit to minimize/stop this, but some started crying they are being repressed.you still arguing over HD costs?... pathetic.. when silly people think tx fee of $20-$100 is fine for ONE tx, but thinks a $70 HD for 15 years of transaction data is too much, seems you have maths backwardsyes when the devs flipped from saying 1mb+=unsafe for network to 4mb=safe for network, they should have listened to the critics warning them of the impending junk,  put limits on tx length maximums so that people cant just junk up a tx with 4mb of crap, yes they should have allowed all tx data into the 4mb space and not just the witness, then we could have more tx per blockyes we should have proper validation rules that dont 'assume-valid' anything and actually have rules a tx has to comply with to ensure each byte has a proper purposebut when core devs care less about blockchain efficiency and only care about roadmaps that follow ideologies of their sponsors, whereby bloating bitcoins blockchain is a goal to win their golden contract bonuses. just goes to show how little the core devs care about efficiency, lean tx, true validation and where every byte counts and tx how counts should scale up to allow more access without fee war competition

comments.body: This madness will never end.Ordinal = NFTs on BTCRunes = ERC20 on BTCIt's the same narrative that happened on the alts blockchain. People spend fees on a tx to create a new shitcoin on runes > list it on unisat > dump it > mint another shitcoin.

comments.author: pinggoki
comments.body: As long as people are making money off of runes, I don't think that we will never see an end to this kind of stuff, it's already been too long for this kind of stuff already and I don't get the hype of it, it's not even making it big in the crypto space and people aren't talking too much about it in a good way so it's really weird that they've persisted for so long. @d5000 is right though, it's a slow death because eventually, people would get tired of it and I do hope that it does, maybe when a new thing in crypto happens, we would see a total decline with runes and inscriptions in crypto, for people that are still doing this, they must really hate other people using bitcoin for transactions so they do their best to slow down the network.
